page.title: 14HISTORY OF GARFORTH
page.content: Although Garforth is mentioned as having a church and a priest in the Domesday Book, the settlement is best known as a mining village from about two hundred years ago. As you walk round Garforth you can see tips or spoil heaps where rubbish from down the mines has been dumped. Coal used to be carried from Garforth to Aberford, about two miles away, by railway. The line was called the Fly Line. It has been closed for about fifty years, but you can still walk down the old track. The mines were owned by the Gascoigne family and were named after them, for example, the Isabella Pit. The Gascoignes used to live in a large mansion in Parlington Park on the edge of Garforth. The house has been demolished, but there is still a footpath you can use to walk through the park.
